I was a pads only chick, only using a tampon when I was caught off guard, unprepared for Aunt Flo ' s arrival. I can't fully empty my bladder with a tampon in, so they are useless as a daily option. I'd felt guilty for a long time, polluting the way I was, with all those smelly lady diapers in the trash. I bought a couple of the fancy, cloth, snap on reusable pads, but was not thrilled at the price point of the ones I bought, or the thought of having to wash them.The cup is great! I still use the cloth reusables for light days, or as back up on that 1st cup use day, (cup users sometimes pass an Itty bitty drop or 2 from what was in there before cup insertion). You may ask, what about all those heavy duty, medical grade silicone cups that will end up in the trash? The brand I bought is meant to be burned, not thrown away when you're ready to dispose of it. So yes, it produces 0% waste! That last part is not a joke, and actually surprised me when I was reading about the brand. I can't think of anything more fitting to do with a period product than shouting a good "toss off!" Then chucking it into a fireplace or campfire 😂 I'm 38, and if this old dog could try these things out, any woman can. BTW, cleaning the cloth pads isn't as bad as I thought it would be.

Don't forget that pads also come with LOTS of waste and often contain perfume which is bad for the ph balance in your vagina. For pads there are also better alternatives, such as reusable pads. Better for your vagina, and better for the planet <3

I've noticed a lot of gals in the comments not wanting to use menstrual cups simply because they're confused about them. I would like to debunk and share my research and experience because I'd recommend these to anyone.

-It's not made of plastic. It's generally made of silicon and FDA approved.
-No, you do not feel it. I actually feel the cup less than I did tampons. For the first I believe two times, yes, it did hurt a little but your body adjusts.
-You don't just 'shove the cup up there.' You fold it so that it's about the size of a tampon when you put it in.
-Taking them out isn't a problem. I think I've spilled maybe once, right at the very beginning. Do it over the stool and flush it down.
-You can keep them in for so long. When in a pinch, I kept mine in for 24+ hours and not one leak.
-There is SIGNIFICANTLY less odor when you use a cup.
-At least in my experience, and I've heard from several other users, your period becomes lighter and doesn't last as long.
-You can be active in these suckers. I play volleyball and do track and field (I do jumps and sprinting, so very active) and I don't have any leaking issues.
-There's no crinkling of tampon/pad wrappers in the bathroom. Cups typically come with decorative cloth bags to store them in.
-You can enjoy way more foreplay on your period than you would with a tampon.
-I personally feel healthier when wearing one.

Honestly to anyone on the fence about it who might be 'scared,' please don't be. I paid $25 for mine, and it should last 10 years. That's a $25 investment as opposed to a $1,000 investment, presuming I spent the average $100 per year on tampons. There are tons and tons of options, and if you do your research, it's likely you'll find one that's right for you.

As a male, watching this video was quite an educational endeavor for me. First off, I agree with many of you who have also commented that the luxury tax on tampons is ridiculous. Feminine hygiene is not a luxury and the products to help keep yourself clean should not be taxed as such. This can only lead to poor financial outcomes or, even worse, poor health outcomes. Some women being able to afford fewer tampons than are necessary could potentially lead to longer times between changing them out by necessity. This could potentially lead to higher incidence of toxic shock syndrome. Alternative products like menstrual cups seem like a decent way to help alleviate some of this issue. Additionally, as the video mentions, there are several benefits to using menstrual cups. Having the blood available for at home medical tests could help increase overall health awareness for many individuals. This awareness could help to detect certain conditions very earl on in their progression. In addition, this would be a MUCH easier and ethical way to collect stem cells. There is no harm involved, donating the sample would be completely voluntary, the samples could potentially bring a minor source of income to low income families, and this could prevent harvesting stem cells from other, more painful methods.

I tried the menstrual cup, and hated the menstrual cup.

I couldn't get it to fit and I felt it uncomfortably inside me all day, kind of like it was falling out. I still stained my clothes, and it was horrible to try to dump it out and wash it, especially if you take birth control, which makes your lining come out thick/clotted/mucus-y, and even worse, stringy.

I'm sure if I had tried it more I could have grown to like it, but I just couldn't figure out how the hell I was supposed to stuff it up there, because it just wouldn't fit in, and I had a small sized one. A tampon is small. A menstrual cup + your hand to push it up and then twist it to get it to suction, that was just ridiculous. Not to mention when you pull it out, it's suctioned like a vacuum, and it felt like I was trying to rip out my insides.

I was also super emotional at the time (yay periods) so I cried and gave up angrily that I was doomed to forever wear tampons.

Everybody should switch to menstrual cups!
A lot of people don't know about these awesome little things. I use a menstrual cup made by the company Lunette, but there are a ton of different companies, Diva Cup is most known in the U.S.
Most Reusable Menstrual Cups are made of medical grade silicone and are much better for your body, as they don't suck excess moisture out of your body! They just collect menstrual fluid and you dump it out every 8-12 hours, or depending on how heavy your flow is. They are much more comfortable than tampons since you don't have a nasty string hanging out of you!
I suggest you research more into it if you'd like to make the switch! You won't regret it :)
